Jestã‚ªãƒ–ã‚¸ã‚§ã‚¯ãƒˆ

jest ã‚ªãƒ–ã‚¸ã‚§ã‚¯ãƒˆã¯ã€ã™ã¹ã¦ã®ãƒ†ã‚¹ãƒˆãƒ•ã‚¡ã‚¤ãƒ«å†…ã§è‡ªå‹•çš„ã«ã‚¹ã‚³ãƒ¼ãƒ—ã•ã‚Œã¾ã™ã€‚ jest ã‚ªãƒ–ã‚¸ã‚§ã‚¯ãƒˆã®ãƒ¡ã‚½ãƒƒãƒ‰ã¯ãƒ¢ãƒƒã‚¯ã®ä½œæˆã«å½¹ç«‹ã¡ã€Jestã®å…¨ä½“çš„ãªå‹•ä½œã‚’åˆ¶å¾¡ã§ãã¾ã™ã€‚ import {jest} from '@jest/globals' ã‚’ä»‹ã—ã¦æ˜ç¤ºçš„ã«ã‚¤ãƒ³ãƒãƒ¼ãƒˆã™ã‚‹ã“ã¨ã‚‚ã§ãã¾ã™ã€‚

info

ã“ã®ãƒšãƒ¼ã‚¸ã® TypeScript ã®ä¾‹ã¯ã€Jest ã®APIã‚’æ˜ç¤ºçš„ã«ã‚¤ãƒ³ãƒãƒ¼ãƒˆã—ãŸå ´åˆã«ã®ã¿å‹•ä½œã—ã¾ã™ã€‚

import {expect, jest, test} from '@jest/globals';

Consult the Getting Started guide for details on how to setup Jest with TypeScript.

ãƒ¡ã‚½ãƒƒãƒ‰â€‹

ãƒ¢ãƒƒã‚¯ãƒ¢ã‚¸ãƒ¥ãƒ¼ãƒ«â€‹

jest.disableAutomock()â€‹

ãƒ¢ã‚¸ãƒ¥ãƒ¼ãƒ«ãƒ­ãƒ¼ãƒ€ãƒ¼ã®è‡ªå‹•ãƒ¢ãƒƒã‚¯æ©Ÿèƒ½ã‚’ç„¡åŠ¹ã«ã—ã¾ã™ã€‚

info

Automatic mocking should be enabled via automock configuration option for this method to have any effect. Also see documentation of the configuration option for more details.

  • JavaScript
  • TypeScript
/** @type {import('jest').Config} */
const config = {
  automock: true,
};

module.exports = config;
import type {Config} from 'jest';

const config: Config = {
  automock: true,
};

export default config;

After disableAutomock() is called, all require()s will return the real versions of each module (rather than a mocked version).

utils.js
export default {
  authorize: () => {
    return 'token';
  },
};
__tests__/disableAutomocking.js
import utils from '../utils';

jest.disableAutomock();

test('original implementation', () => {
  // now we have the original implementation,
  // even if we set the automocking in a jest configuration
  expect(utils.authorize()).toBe('token');
});

ã“ã®é–¢æ•°ã¯ãƒ¢ãƒƒã‚¯ã—ãŸã„ä¾å­˜é–¢ä¿‚ãŒã€ãƒ¢ãƒƒã‚¯ãŒè¦ã‚‰ãªã„ã‚‚ã®ã‚ˆã‚Šã‚‚ã¯ã‚‹ã‹ã«å°‘ãªã„ã‚·ãƒŠãƒªã‚ªãŒã‚ã‚‹å ´åˆã«ä¾¿åˆ©ã§ã™ã€‚ ä¾‹ãˆã°ã€"implementation details"ã¨ã—ã¦åˆ†é¡ã•␀ã‚Œã‚‹ã®ãŒå¦¥å½“ãªå¤§é‡ã®ä¾å­˜é–¢ä¿‚ã‚’æŒã¤ãƒ¢ã‚¸ãƒ¥ãƒ¼ãƒ«ã®ãƒ†ã‚¹ãƒˆæ›¸ãå ´åˆã€ãã‚Œã‚‰ã‚’ãƒ¢ãƒƒã‚¯ã—ãŸã„ã¨ã¯æ€ã‚ãªã„ã§ã—ã‚‡ã†ã€‚

Examples of dependencies that might be considered "implementation details" are things ranging from language built-ins (e.g. Array.prototype methods) to highly common utility methods (e.g. underscore, lodash, array utilities, etc) and entire libraries like React.js.

ãƒ¡ã‚½ãƒƒãƒ‰ãƒã‚§ãƒ¼ãƒ³ã®ãŸã‚ã«jestã‚ªãƒ–ã‚¸ã‚§ã‚¯ãƒˆã‚’è¿”ã—ã¾ã™ã€‚

tip

When using babel-jest, calls to disableAutomock() will automatically be hoisted to the top of the code block. Use autoMockOff() if you want to explicitly avoid this behavior.

jest.enableAutomock()â€‹

ãƒ¢ã‚¸ãƒ¥ãƒ¼ãƒ«ãƒ­ãƒ¼ãƒ€ãƒ¼ã§è‡ªå‹•ãƒ¢ãƒƒã‚¯æ©Ÿèƒ½ã‚’æœ‰åŠ¹åŒ–ã—ã¾ã™ã€‚

info

For more details on automatic mocking see documentation of automock configuration option.

ä¾‹:

utils.js
export default {
  authorize: () => {
    return 'token';
  },
  isAuthorized: secret => secret === 'wizard',
};
__tests__/enableAutomocking.js
jest.enableAutomock();

import utils from '../utils';

test('original implementation', () => {
  // now we have the mocked implementation,
  expect(utils.authorize._isMockFunction).toBeTruthy();
  expect(utils.isAuthorized._isMockFunction).toBeTruthy();
});

ãƒ¡ã‚½ãƒƒãƒ‰ãƒã‚§ãƒ¼ãƒ³ã®ãŸã‚ã«jestã‚ªãƒ–ã‚¸ã‚§ã‚¯ãƒˆã‚’è¿”ã—ã¾ã™ã€‚

tip

babel-jestã‚’ä½¿ç”¨ã—ã¦ã„ã‚‹å ´åˆã¯ã€enableAutomockã®å‘¼ã³å‡ºã—ã¯è‡ªå‹•çš„ã«ã‚³ãƒ¼ãƒ‰ã®å…ˆé ­ã§è¡Œã‚ã‚Œã¾ã™ã€‚ ã“ã®å‹•ä½œã‚’é¿ã‘ã‚‹ã«ã¯autoMockOn ã‚’æ˜ç¤ºçš„ã«ä½¿ç”¨ã—ã¦ä¸‹ã•ã„ã€‚

jest.createMockFromModule(moduleName)â€‹

ä¸ãˆã‚‰ã‚ŒãŸåå‰ã®ãƒ¢ã‚¸ãƒ¥ãƒ¼ãƒ«ã«å¯¾ã—ã¦è‡ªå‹•ãƒ¢ãƒƒã‚¯åŒ–ã‚·ã‚¹ãƒ†ãƒ ã‚’åˆ©ç”¨ã—ã¦ãƒ¢ãƒƒã‚¯åŒ–ã—ãŸãƒ¢ã‚¸ãƒ¥ãƒ¼ãƒ«ã‚’ä½œæˆã—ã¾ã™ã€‚

This is useful when you want to create a manual mock that extends the automatic mock's behavior:

  • JavaScript
  • TypeScript
utils.js
module.exports = {
  authorize: () => {
    return 'token';
  },
  isAuthorized: secret => secret === 'wizard',
};
__tests__/createMockFromModule.test.js
const utils = jest.createMockFromModule('../utils');

utils.isAuthorized = jest.fn(secret => secret === 'not wizard');

test('implementation created by jest.createMockFromModule', () => {
  expect(jest.isMockFunction(utils.authorize)).toBe(true);
  expect(utils.isAuthorized('not wizard')).toBe(true);
});
utils.ts
export const utils = {
  authorize: () => {
    return 'token';
  },
  isAuthorized: (secret: string) => secret === 'wizard',
};
__tests__/createMockFromModule.test.ts
const {utils} =
  jest.createMockFromModule<typeof import('../utils')>('../utils');

utils.isAuthorized = jest.fn((secret: string) => secret === 'not wizard');

test('implementation created by jest.createMockFromModule', () => {
  expect(jest.isMockFunction(utils.authorize)).toBe(true);
  expect(utils.isAuthorized('not wizard')).toBe(true);
});

createMockFromModule ãŒä»¥ä¸‹ã®ãƒ‡ãƒ¼ã‚¿å‹ã‚’ãƒ¢ãƒƒã‚¯ã™ã‚‹æ–¹æ³•ã§ã™ã€‚

é–¢æ•°â€‹

Creates a new mock function. The new function has no formal parameters and when called will return undefined. This functionality also applies to async functions.

ã‚¯ãƒ©ã‚¹â€‹

Creates a new class. The interface of the original class is maintained, all of the class member functions and properties will be mocked.

ã‚ªãƒ–ã‚¸ã‚§ã‚¯ãƒˆâ€‹

ãƒ‡ã‚£ãƒ¼ãƒ—ã‚¯ãƒ­ãƒ¼ãƒ³ã•ã‚ŒãŸæ–°ã—ã„ã‚ªãƒ–ã‚¸ã‚§ã‚¯ãƒˆã‚’ä½œæˆã—ã¾ã™ã€‚ ã‚ªãƒ–ã‚¸ã‚§ã‚¯ãƒˆã‚­ãƒ¼ã¯ç¶­æŒã•ã‚Œã€ãã®å€¤ã¯ãƒ¢ãƒƒã‚¯ã•ã‚Œã¾ã™ã€‚

â€‹

Creates a new empty array, ignoring the original.

ãƒ—ãƒªãƒŸãƒ†ã‚£ãƒ–å‹â€‹

Creates a new property with the same primitive value as the original property.

ä¾‹:

example.js
module.exports = {
  function: function square(a, b) {
    return a * b;
  },
  asyncFunction: async function asyncSquare(a, b) {
    const result = (await a) * b;
    return result;
  },
  class: new (class Bar {
    constructor() {
      this.array = [1, 2, 3];
    }
    foo() {}
  })(),
  object: {
    baz: 'foo',
    bar: {
      fiz: 1,
      buzz: [1, 2, 3],
    },
  },
  array: [1, 2, 3],
  number: 123,
  string: 'baz',
  boolean: true,
  symbol: Symbol.for('a.b.c'),
};
__tests__/example.test.js
const example = jest.createMockFromModule('../example');

test('should run example code', () => {
  // creates a new mocked function with no formal arguments.
  expect(example.function.name).toBe('square');
  expect(example.function).toHaveLength(0);

  // async functions get the same treatment as standard synchronous functions.
  expect(example.asyncFunction.name).toBe('asyncSquare');
  expect(example.asyncFunction).toHaveLength(0);

  // creates a new class with the same interface, member functions and properties are mocked.
  expect(example.class.constructor.name).toBe('Bar');
  expect(example.class.foo.name).toBe('foo');
  expect(example.class.array).toHaveLength(0);

  // creates a deeply cloned version of the original object.
  expect(example.object).toEqual({
    baz: 'foo',
    bar: {
      fiz: 1,
      buzz: [],
    },
  });

  // creates a new empty array, ignoring the original array.
  expect(example.array).toHaveLength(0);

  // creates a new property with the same primitive value as the original property.
  expect(example.number).toBe(123);
  expect(example.string).toBe('baz');
  expect(example.boolean).toBe(true);
  expect(example.symbol).toEqual(Symbol.for('a.b.c'));
});

jest.mock(moduleName, factory, options)â€‹

requireã•ã‚ŒãŸéš›ã«è‡ªå‹•ãƒ¢ãƒƒã‚¯åŒ–ã•ã‚ŒãŸãƒ¢ã‚¸ãƒ¥ãƒ¼ãƒ«ã®ãƒ¢ãƒƒã‚¯ã‚’ä½œæˆã—ã¾ã™ã€‚ factory ã¨ optionsã¯ã‚ªãƒ—ã‚·ãƒ§ãƒ³ã§ã™ã€‚ ä¾‹ï¼š

banana.js
module.exports = () => 'banana';
__tests__/test.js
jest.mock('../banana');

const banana = require('../banana'); // banana will be explicitly mocked.

banana(); // will return 'undefined' because the function is auto-mocked.

ç¬¬ï¼’å¼•æ•°ã¯Jestã®è‡ªå‹•ãƒ¢ãƒƒã‚¯ã«ã‚ˆã‚‹è¨­å®šã‚’ç”¨ã„ã‚‹ä»£ã‚ã‚Šã«æ˜ç¤ºçš„ã«ãƒ¢ã‚¸ãƒ¥ãƒ¼ãƒ«ã®ãƒ•ã‚¡ã‚¯ãƒˆãƒªã‚’æŒ‡å®šã™ã‚‹å ´åˆã«ä½¿ç”¨ã—ã¾ã™ã€‚

  • JavaScript
  • TypeScript
jest.mock('../moduleName', () => {
  return jest.fn(() => 42);
});

// This runs the function specified as second argument to `jest.mock`.
const moduleName = require('../moduleName');
moduleName(); // Will return '42';
// The optional type argument provides typings for the module factory
jest.mock<typeof import('../moduleName')>('../moduleName', () => {
  return jest.fn(() => 42);
});

// This runs the function specified as second argument to `jest.mock`.
const moduleName = require('../moduleName');
moduleName(); // Will return '42';

ãƒ‡ãƒ•ã‚©ãƒ«ãƒˆã®ã‚¨ã‚¯ã‚¹ãƒãƒ¼ãƒˆã®ES6ãƒ¢ã‚¸ãƒ¥ãƒ¼ãƒ«ã§ factory ãƒ‘ãƒ©ãƒ¡ãƒ¼ã‚¿ã‚’ä½¿ç”¨ã™ã‚‹å ´åˆã€ __esModule: true ãƒ—ãƒ­ãƒ‘ãƒ†ã‚£ã‚’æŒ‡å®šã™ã‚‹å¿…è¦ãŒã‚ã‚Šã¾ã™ã€‚ é€šå¸¸ã€ã“ã®ãƒ—ãƒ­ãƒ‘ãƒ†ã‚£ã¯ Babel / TypeScript ã«ã‚ˆã£ã¦ç”Ÿæˆã•ã‚Œã¾ã™ãŒã€ã“ã“ã§ã¯æ‰‹å‹•ã§è¨­å®šã™ã‚‹å¿…è¦ãŒã‚ã‚Šã¾ã™ã€‚ ãƒ‡ãƒ•ã‚©ãƒ«ãƒˆã‚¨ã‚¯ã‚¹ãƒãƒ¼ãƒˆã‚’ã‚¤ãƒ³ãƒãƒ¼ãƒˆã™ã‚‹å ´åˆã€ã‚¨ã‚¯ã‚¹ãƒãƒ¼ãƒˆã‚ªãƒ–ã‚¸ã‚§ã‚¯ãƒˆã‹ã‚‰ default ã¨ã„ã†åå‰ã®ãƒ—ãƒ­ãƒ‘ãƒ†ã‚£ã‚’ã‚¤ãƒ³ãƒãƒ¼ãƒˆã—ã¾ã™ã€‚

import moduleName, {foo} from '../moduleName';

jest.mock('../moduleName', () => {
  return {
    __esModule: true,
    default: jest.fn(() => 42),
    foo: jest.fn(() => 43),
  };
});

moduleName(); // 42ã‚’è¿”ã—ã¾ã™
foo(); // 43ã‚’è¿”ã—ã¾ã™

ç¬¬ï¼“å¼•æ•°ã¯ä»®æƒ³ãƒ¢ãƒƒã‚¯ã‚’ä½œæˆã™ã‚‹ã®ã«ä½¿ç”¨ã—ã¾ã™ - ã“ã‚Œã¯ã‚·ã‚¹ãƒ†ãƒ å†…ã®ã©ã“ã«ã‚‚å­˜åœ¨ã—ãªã„ãƒ¢ã‚¸ãƒ¥ãƒ¼ãƒ«ã®ãƒ¢ãƒƒã‚¯ã§ã™ã€‚

jest.mock(
  '../moduleName',
  () => {
    /*
     * Custom implementation of a module that doesn't exist in JS,
     * like a generated module or a native module in react-native.
     */
  },
  {virtual: true},
);
caution

Importing a module in a setup file (as specified by setupFilesAfterEnv) will prevent mocking for the module in question, as well as all the modules that it imports.

jest.mockã«ã‚ˆã‚Šãƒ¢ãƒƒã‚¯ã•ã‚Œã‚‹ãƒ¢ã‚¸ãƒ¥ãƒ¼ãƒ«ã¯ã€jest.mockã‚’å‘¼ã³å‡ºã—ãŸãƒ•ã‚¡ã‚¤ãƒ«å†…ã§ã®ã¿ãƒ¢ãƒƒã‚¯ã•ã‚Œã¾ã™ã€‚ ãƒ¢ã‚¸ãƒ¥ãƒ¼ãƒ«ã‚’ãƒ¢ãƒƒã‚¯ã—ãŸãƒ†ã‚¹ãƒˆã®å¾Œã«å®Ÿè¡Œã—ãŸã¨ã—ã¦ã‚‚ã€ãã®ãƒ¢ã‚¸ãƒ¥ãƒ¼ãƒ«ã‚’ã‚¤ãƒ³ãƒãƒ¼ãƒˆã™ã‚‹åˆ¥ã®ãƒ•ã‚¡ã‚¤ãƒ«ã§ã¯ã€æœ¬ç‰©ã®ãƒ¢ã‚¸ãƒ¥ãƒ¼ãƒ«ãŒã‚¤ãƒ³ãƒãƒ¼ãƒˆã•ã‚Œã¾ã™ã€‚

ãƒ¡ã‚½ãƒƒãƒ‰ãƒã‚§ãƒ¼ãƒ³ã®ãŸã‚ã«jestã‚ªãƒ–ã‚¸ã‚§ã‚¯ãƒˆã‚’è¿”ã—ã¾ã™ã€‚

tip

Writing tests in TypeScript? Use the jest.Mocked utility type or the jest.mocked() helper method to have your mocked modules typed.

jest.Mocked<Source>â€‹

See TypeScript Usage chapter of Mock Functions page for documentation.

jest.mocked(source, options?)â€‹

See TypeScript Usage chapter of Mock Functions page for documentation.

jest.unmock(moduleName)â€‹

æŒ‡å®šã—ãŸãƒ¢ã‚¸ãƒ¥ãƒ¼ãƒ«ã«ã¤ã„ã¦require()ã—ãŸéš›ã«ã€ãƒ¢ã‚¸ãƒ¥ãƒ¼ãƒ«ã‚·ã‚¹ãƒ†ãƒ ã¯æ±ºã—ã¦ãƒ¢ãƒƒã‚¯ã—ãŸã‚‚ã®ã‚’è¿”ã•ãªã„ã“ã¨ã‚’è¨­å®šã—ã¾ã™(ä¾‹ãˆã°å¸¸ã«æœ¬ç‰©ã®ãƒ¢ã‚¸ãƒ¥ãƒ¼ãƒ«ã‚’è¿”ã™ã¹ãå ´åˆãªã©)ã€‚

ã“ã®APIã®æœ€ã‚‚ä¸€èˆ¬çš„ãªç”¨é€”ã¯ã€æŒ‡å®šã•ã‚ŒãŸãƒ¢ã‚¸ãƒ¥ãƒ¼ãƒ«ã‚’ä¸ãˆã‚‰ã‚ŒãŸãƒ†ã‚¹ãƒˆãƒ•ã‚¡ã‚¤ãƒ«ã§ãƒ†ã‚¹ãƒˆã—ã‚ˆã†ã¨ã—ã¦ã„ã‚‹å ´åˆ(ãã®ãŸã‚è‡ªå‹•çš„ã«ãƒ¢ãƒƒã‚¯ã‚’ã—ãŸããªã„å ´åˆ) ã§ã™ã€‚

ãƒ¡ã‚½ãƒƒãƒ‰ãƒã‚§ãƒ¼ãƒ³ã®ãŸã‚ã«jestã‚ªãƒ–ã‚¸ã‚§ã‚¯ãƒˆã‚’è¿”ã—ã¾ã™ã€‚

jest.deepUnmock(moduleName)â€‹

Indicates that the module system should never return a mocked version of the specified module and its dependencies.

ãƒ¡ã‚½ãƒƒãƒ‰ãƒã‚§ãƒ¼ãƒ³ã®ãŸã‚ã«jestã‚ªãƒ–ã‚¸ã‚§ã‚¯ãƒˆã‚’è¿”ã—ã¾ã™ã€‚

jest.doMock(moduleName, factory, options)â€‹

babel-jestã‚’ä½¿ç”¨ã—ã¦ã„ã‚‹å ´åˆã€ mock ã®å‘¼ã³å‡ºã—ã¯è‡ªå‹•çš„ã«ã‚³ãƒ¼ãƒ‰ãƒ–ãƒ­ãƒƒã‚¯ã®å…ˆé ­ã§è¡Œã‚ã‚Œã¾ã™ã€‚ ã“ã®æŒ¯ã‚‹èˆã„ã‚’æ˜ç¤ºçš„ã«é¿ã‘ã‚‹ã«ã¯ã“ã®ãƒ¡ã‚½ãƒƒãƒ‰ã‚’ä½¿ç”¨ã—ã¦ãã ã•ã„ã€‚

ã“ã®é–¢æ•°ãŒæœ‰ç”¨ãªä¾‹ã®ï¼‘ã¤ã¨ã—ã¦ã€åŒä¸€ãƒ•ã‚¡ã‚¤ãƒ«å†…ã§ç•°ãªã‚‹æŒ¯ã‚‹èˆã„ã®ãƒ¢ãƒƒã‚¯ã‚’ä½¿ç”¨ã—ãŸã„å ´åˆãŒæŒ™ã’ã‚‰ã‚Œã¾ã™:

  • JavaScript
  • TypeScript
beforeEach(() => {
  jest.resetModules();
});

test('moduleName 1', () => {
  jest.doMock('../moduleName', () => {
    return jest.fn(() => 1);
  });
  const moduleName = require('../moduleName');
  expect(moduleName()).toBe(1);
});

test('moduleName 2', () => {
  jest.doMock('../moduleName', () => {
    return jest.fn(() => 2);
  });
  const moduleName = require('../moduleName');
  expect(moduleName()).toBe(2);
});
beforeEach(() => {
  jest.resetModules();
});

test('moduleName 1', () => {
  // The optional type argument provides typings for the module factory
  jest.doMock<typeof import('../moduleName')>('../moduleName', () => {
    return jest.fn(() => 1);
  });
  const moduleName = require('../moduleName');
  expect(moduleName()).toBe(1);
});

test('moduleName 2', () => {
  jest.doMock<typeof import('../moduleName')>('../moduleName', () => {
    return jest.fn(() => 2);
  });
  const moduleName = require('../moduleName');
  expect(moduleName()).toBe(2);
});

ES6 ã‚¤ãƒ³ãƒãƒ¼ãƒˆã§ jest.doMock() ã‚’ä½¿ç”¨ã™ã‚‹ã«ã¯ã€è¿½åŠ ã®æ‰‹é †ãŒå¿…è¦ã§ã™ã€‚ ãƒ†ã‚¹ãƒˆã§ require ã‚’ä½¿ç”¨ã—ãŸããªã„å ´åˆã¯ã€æ¬¡ã®æ‰‹é †ã«å¾“ã£ã¦ãã ã•ã„ã€‚

  • æœ€å¾Œã«ã€å‹•çš„ã‚¤ãƒ³ãƒãƒ¼ãƒˆã‚’ã‚µãƒãƒ¼ãƒˆã™ã‚‹ç’°å¢ƒãŒå¿…è¦ã§ã™ã€‚ åˆæœŸè¨­å®šã«ã¤ã„ã¦ã¯ã€ Using Babel ã‚’å‚ç…§ã—ã¦ãã ã•ã„ã€‚ æ¬¡ã«ã€ãƒ—ãƒ©ã‚°ã‚¤ãƒ³ babel-plugin-dynamic-import-nodeã€ã¾ãŸã¯åŒç­‰ã®ã‚‚ã®ã‚’ Babel ã®è¨­å®šã«è¿½åŠ ã—ã¦ã€Node ã§ã®å‹•çš„ã‚¤ãƒ³ãƒãƒ¼ãƒˆã‚’æœ‰åŠ¹ã«ã—ã¾ã™ã€‚
beforeEach(() => {
  jest.resetModules();
});

  jest.doMock('../moduleName', () => {
    return {
      __esModule: true,
      default: 'default1',
      foo: 'foo1',
    };
  });
  return import('../moduleName').then(moduleName => {
    expect(moduleName.default).toBe('default1');
    expect(moduleName.foo).toBe('foo1');
  });

  jest.doMock('../moduleName', () => {
    return {
      __esModule: true,
      default: 'default2',
      foo: 'foo2',
    };
  });
  return import('../moduleName').then(moduleName => {
    expect(moduleName.default).toBe('default2');
    expect(moduleName.foo).toBe('foo2');
  });

ãƒ¡ã‚½ãƒƒãƒ‰ãƒã‚§ãƒ¼ãƒ³ã®ãŸã‚ã«jestã‚ªãƒ–ã‚¸ã‚§ã‚¯ãƒˆã‚’è¿”ã—ã¾ã™ã€‚

jest.dontMock(moduleName)â€‹

babel-jestã‚’ä½¿ç”¨ã—ã¦ã„ã‚‹å ´åˆã€ unmock ã®å‘¼ã³å‡ºã—ã¯è‡ªå‹•çš„ã«ã‚³ãƒ¼ãƒ‰ãƒ–ãƒ­ãƒƒã‚¯ã®å…ˆé ­ã§è¡Œã‚ã‚Œã¾ã™ã€‚ ã“ã®æŒ¯ã‚‹èˆã„ã‚’æ˜ç¤ºçš„ã«é¿ã‘ã‚‹ã«ã¯ã“ã®ãƒ¡ã‚½ãƒƒãƒ‰ã‚’ä½¿ç”¨ã—ã¦ãã ã•ã„ã€‚

ãƒ¡ã‚½ãƒƒãƒ‰ãƒã‚§ãƒ¼ãƒ³ã®ãŸã‚ã«jestã‚ªãƒ–ã‚¸ã‚§ã‚¯ãƒˆã‚’è¿”ã—ã¾ã™ã€‚

jest.setMock(moduleName, moduleExports)â€‹

æŒ‡å®šã•ã‚ŒãŸãƒ¢ã‚¸ãƒ¥ãƒ¼ãƒ«ã«ã¤ã„ã¦ãƒ¢ã‚¸␀␀ãƒ¥ãƒ¼ãƒ«ã‚·ã‚¹ãƒ†ãƒ ãŒè¿”ã™ã¹ããƒ¢ãƒƒã‚¯ã‚ªãƒ–ã‚¸ã‚§ã‚¯ãƒˆã‚’æ˜ç¤ºçš„ã«ä¸ãˆã¾ã™ã€‚

On occasion, there are times where the automatically generated mock the module system would normally provide you isn't adequate enough for your testing needs. é€šå¸¸ãã®ã‚ˆã†ãªçŠ¶æ³ã§ã¯å½“è©²ã®ãƒ¢ã‚¸ãƒ¥ãƒ¼ãƒ«ã«ã‚ˆã‚Šé©ã—ãŸãƒãƒ‹ãƒ¥ã‚¢ãƒ«ãƒ¢ãƒƒã‚¯ã‚’ä½œæˆã™ã‚‹ã¹ãã§ã™ã€‚ ã—ã‹ã—ã¨ã¦ã‚‚ç¨€ã§ã™ãŒã€ãƒãƒ‹ãƒ¥ã‚¢ãƒ«ãƒ¢ãƒƒã‚¯ã§ã™ã‚‰ç›®çš„ã«å¯¾ã—ã¦é©åˆ‡ã§ãªããƒ†ã‚¹ãƒˆå†…ã§ãƒ¢ãƒƒã‚¯ã‚’ä½œæˆã™ã‚‹å¿…è¦ãŒã‚ã‚‹ã‚±ãƒ¼ã‚¹ãŒã‚ã‚Šã¾ã™ã€‚

ã“ã‚Œã‚‰ã®ç¨€ãªã‚·ãƒŠãƒªã‚ªã§ã¯ã€ã“ã®APIã§ãƒ¢ã‚¸ãƒ¥ãƒ¼ãƒ«ã‚·ã‚¹ãƒ†ãƒ ã®ãƒ¢ãƒƒã‚¯ãƒ¢ã‚¸ãƒ¥ãƒ¼ãƒ«ã®ãƒ¬ã‚¸ã‚¹ãƒˆãƒªã®ã‚¹ãƒ­ãƒƒãƒˆã«æ‰‹å‹•ã§è¨­å®šã™ã‚‹ã“ã¨ãŒã§ãã¾ã™ã€‚

ãƒ¡ã‚½ãƒƒãƒ‰ãƒã‚§ãƒ¼ãƒ³ã®ãŸã‚ã«jestã‚ªãƒ–ã‚¸ã‚§ã‚¯ãƒˆã‚’è¿”ã—ã¾ã™ã€‚

info

It is recommended to use jest.mock() instead. jest.mockAPIã®ç¬¬ï¼’å¼•æ•°ã¯ã‚¨ã‚¯ã‚¹ãƒãƒ¼ãƒˆã•ã‚ŒãŸãƒ¢ã‚¸ãƒ¥ãƒ¼ãƒ«ã®ã‚ªãƒ–ã‚¸ã‚§ã‚¯ãƒˆã®ä»£æ›¿ã¨ãªã‚‹ãƒ¢ã‚¸ãƒ¥ãƒ¼ãƒ«ã®ãƒ•ã‚¡ã‚¯ãƒˆãƒªã‚’æŒ‡å®šã§ãã¾ã™ã€‚

jest.requireActual(moduleName)â€‹

ãƒ¢ã‚¸ãƒ¥ãƒ¼ãƒ«ãŒãƒ¢ãƒƒã‚¯ã—ãŸã‚‚ã®ã‚’å—ã‘å–ã‚‹è¨­å®šã§ã‚ã‚‹ã‹ã‚’ç¢ºèªã›ãšã€ãƒ¢ãƒƒã‚¯ã§ã¯ãªã„æœ¬ç‰©ã®ãƒ¢ã‚¸ãƒ¥ãƒ¼ãƒ«ã‚’è¿”ã™ã‚ˆã†ã«ãªã‚Šã¾ã™ã€‚

  • JavaScript
  • TypeScript
jest.mock('../myModule', () => {
  // Require the original module to not be mocked...
  const originalModule = jest.requireActual('../myModule');

  return {
    __esModule: true, // Use it when dealing with esModules
    ...originalModule,
    getRandom: jest.fn(() => 10),
  };
});

const getRandom = require('../myModule').getRandom;

getRandom(); // Always returns 10
jest.mock('../myModule', () => {
  // Require the original module to not be mocked...
  const originalModule =
    jest.requireActual<typeof import('../myModule')>('../myModule');

  return {
    __esModule: true, // Use it when dealing with esModules
    ...originalModule,
    getRandom: jest.fn(() => 10),
  };
});

const getRandom = require('../myModule').getRandom;

getRandom(); // Always returns 10

jest.requireMock(moduleName)â€‹

ãƒ¢ã‚¸ãƒ¥ãƒ¼ãƒ«ãŒé€šå¸¸é€šã‚Šrequireã•ã‚Œã‚‹ã‹ã‚’ç¢ºèªã›ãšã€æœ¬ç‰©ã®ãƒ¢ã‚¸ãƒ¥ãƒ¼ãƒ«ã§ã¯ãªã„ãƒ¢ãƒƒã‚¯ã‚’è¿”ã™ã‚ˆã†ã«ãªã‚Šã¾ã™ã€‚

jest.resetModules()â€‹

ãƒ¢ã‚¸ãƒ¥ãƒ¼ãƒ«ã®ãƒ¬ã‚¸ã‚¹ãƒˆãƒª - å…¨ã¦ã®requireã•ã‚ŒãŸãƒ¢ã‚¸ãƒ¥ãƒ¼ãƒ« - ã‚’ãƒªã‚»ãƒƒãƒˆã—ã¾ã™ ã€‚ ãƒ†ã‚¹ãƒˆé–“ã§ãƒ­ãƒ¼ã‚«ãƒ«ã®çŠ¶æ…‹ãŒç«¶åˆã—ã†ã‚‹ãƒ¢ã‚¸ãƒ¥ãƒ¼ãƒ«ã®çŠ¶æ…‹ã‚’ãƒ†ã‚¹ãƒˆã”ã¨ã«åˆ‡ã‚Šé›¢ã™ã®ã«å½¹ç«‹ã¡ã¾ã™ã€‚

ä¾‹:

const sum1 = require('../sum');
jest.resetModules();
const sum2 = require('../sum');
sum1 === sum2;
// > false (Both sum modules are separate "instances" of the sum module.)

ãƒ†ã‚¹ãƒˆã«ãŠã‘ã‚‹ä¾‹:

beforeEach(() => {
  jest.resetModules();
});

test('works', () => {
  const sum = require('../sum');
});

test('works too', () => {
  const sum = require('../sum');
  // sum is a different copy of the sum module from the previous test.
});

ãƒ¡ã‚½ãƒƒãƒ‰ãƒã‚§ãƒ¼ãƒ³ã®ãŸã‚ã«jestã‚ªãƒ–ã‚¸ã‚§ã‚¯ãƒˆã‚’è¿”ã—ã¾ã™ã€‚

jest.isolateModules(fn)â€‹

jest.isolateModules(fn) goes a step further than jest.resetModules() and creates a sandbox registry for the modules that are loaded inside the callback function. This is useful to isolate specific modules for every test so that local module state doesn't conflict between tests.

let myModule;
jest.isolateModules(() => {
  myModule = require('myModule');
});

const otherCopyOfMyModule = require('myModule');

jest.isolateModulesAsync(fn)â€‹

jest.isolateModulesAsync() is the equivalent of jest.isolateModules(), but for async callbacks. The caller is expected to await the completion of isolateModulesAsync.

let myModule;
await jest.isolateModulesAsync(async () => {
  myModule = await import('myModule');
  // do async stuff here
});

const otherCopyOfMyModule = await import('myModule');

ãƒ¢ãƒƒã‚¯é–¢æ•°â€‹

jest.fn(implementation?)â€‹

æ–°ã—ã„ã€æœªä½¿ç”¨ã®ãƒ¢ãƒƒã‚¯é–¢æ•°ã‚’è¿”ã—ã¾ã™ã€‚ ã‚ªãƒ—ã‚·ãƒ§ãƒ³ã§ãƒ¢ãƒƒã‚¯ã«å¯¾ã™ã‚‹å®Ÿè£…ã‚’å—ã‘å–ã‚Šã¾ã™ã€‚

const mockFn = jest.fn();
mockFn();
expect(mockFn).toHaveBeenCalled();

// With a mock implementation:
const returnsTrue = jest.fn(() => true);
console.log(returnsTrue()); // true;
tip

See the Mock Functions page for details on TypeScript usage.

jest.isMockFunction(fn)â€‹

ä¸ãˆã‚‰ã‚ŒãŸé–¢æ•°ãŒãƒ¢ãƒƒã‚¯é–¢æ•°ãŒã©ã†ã‹ã‚’è¿”ã—ã¾ã™ã€‚

jest.replaceProperty(object, propertyKey, value)â€‹

Replace object[propertyKey] with a value. The property must already exist on the object. The same property might be replaced multiple times. Returns a Jest replaced property.

note

To mock properties that are defined as getters or setters, use jest.spyOn(object, methodName, accessType) instead. To mock functions, use jest.spyOn(object, methodName) instead.

tip

All properties replaced with jest.replaceProperty could be restored to the original value by calling jest.restoreAllMocks on afterEach method.

ä¾‹:

const utils = {
  isLocalhost() {
    return process.env.HOSTNAME === 'localhost';
  },
};

module.exports = utils;

ãƒ†ã‚¹ãƒˆã®ä¾‹:

const utils = require('./utils');

afterEach(() => {
  // restore replaced property
  jest.restoreAllMocks();
});

test('isLocalhost returns true when HOSTNAME is localhost', () => {
  jest.replaceProperty(process, 'env', {HOSTNAME: 'localhost'});
  expect(utils.isLocalhost()).toBe(true);
});

test('isLocalhost returns false when HOSTNAME is not localhost', () => {
  jest.replaceProperty(process, 'env', {HOSTNAME: 'not-localhost'});
  expect(utils.isLocalhost()).toBe(false);
});

jest.spyOn(object, methodName)â€‹

jest.fnã¨åŒæ§˜ã®é–¢æ•°ã‚’ä½œæˆã—ã¾ã™ãŒã€å¼•æ•°ã«ä¸ãˆã‚‰ã‚ŒãŸobject[methodName]ã¸ã®ã‚³ãƒ¼ãƒ«ã‚‚å®Ÿè£…ã—ã¾ã™ã€‚ Jestã® ãƒ¢ãƒƒã‚¯é–¢æ•°ã‚’è¿”ã—ã¾ã™ã€‚

note

By default, jest.spyOn also calls the spied method. ã“ã‚Œã¯ä»–ã®å¤§æŠµã®ãƒ†ã‚¹ãƒˆãƒ©ã‚¤ãƒ–ãƒ©ãƒªã¨ã¯ç•°ãªã‚‹æŒ¯ã‚‹èˆã„ã§ã™ã€‚ If you want to overwrite the original function, you can use jest.spyOn(object, methodName).mockImplementation(() => customImplementation) or object[methodName] = jest.fn(() => customImplementation).

tip

Since jest.spyOn is a mock, you could restore the initial state by calling jest.restoreAllMocks in the body of the callback passed to the afterEach hook.

ä¾‹:

const video = {
  play() {
    return true;
  },
};

module.exports = video;

ãƒ†ã‚¹ãƒˆã®ä¾‹:

const video = require('./video');

afterEach(() => {
  // restore the spy created with spyOn
  jest.restoreAllMocks();
});

test('plays video', () => {
  const spy = jest.spyOn(video, 'play');
  const isPlaying = video.play();

  expect(spy).toHaveBeenCalled();
  expect(isPlaying).toBe(true);
});

jest.spyOn(object, methodName, accessType?)â€‹

Jest 22.1.0+ ã‹ã‚‰ã¯ jest.spyOn ãƒ¡ã‚½ãƒƒãƒ‰ã¯ã‚ªãƒ—ã‚·ãƒ§ãƒ³ã®ç¬¬3å¼•æ•° accessType ã‚’å–ã‚‹ã‚ˆã†ã«ãªã‚Šã¾ã—ãŸã€‚ ã“ã®å¼•æ•°ã«ã¯ 'get' ã¾ãŸã¯ 'set' ã‚’æŒ‡å®šã™ã‚‹ã“ã¨ãŒã§ãã€ãã‚Œãã‚Œã‚²ãƒƒã‚¿ã‚„ã‚»ãƒƒã‚¿ã‚’ã‚¹ãƒ‘ã‚¤ã—ãŸã„å ´åˆã«ä¾¿åˆ©ã§ã™ã€‚

ä¾‹:

const video = {
  // it's a getter!
  get play() {
    return true;
  },
};

module.exports = video;

const audio = {
  _volume: false,
  // it's a setter!
  set volume(value) {
    this._volume = value;
  },
  get volume() {
    return this._volume;
  },
};

module.exports = audio;

ãƒ†ã‚¹ãƒˆã®ä¾‹:

const audio = require('./audio');
const video = require('./video');

afterEach(() => {
  // restore the spy created with spyOn
  jest.restoreAllMocks();
});

test('plays video', () => {
  const spy = jest.spyOn(video, 'play', 'get'); // we pass 'get'
  const isPlaying = video.play();

  expect(spy).toHaveBeenCalled();
  expect(isPlaying).toBe(true);
});

test('plays audio', () => {
  const spy = jest.spyOn(audio, 'volume', 'set'); // we pass 'set'
  audio.volume = 100;

  expect(spy).toHaveBeenCalled();
  expect(audio.volume).toBe(100);
});

jest.Replaced<Source>â€‹

See TypeScript Usage chapter of Mock Functions page for documentation.

jest.Spied<Source>â€‹

See TypeScript Usage chapter of Mock Functions page for documentation.

jest.clearAllMocks()â€‹

Clears the mock.calls, mock.instances, mock.contexts and mock.results properties of all mocks. Equivalent to calling .mockClear() on every mocked function.

ãƒ¡ã‚½ãƒƒãƒ‰ãƒã‚§ãƒ¼ãƒ³ã®ãŸã‚ã«jestã‚ªãƒ–ã‚¸ã‚§ã‚¯ãƒˆã‚’è¿”ã—ã¾ã™ã€‚

jest.resetAllMocks()â€‹

Resets the state of all mocks. Equivalent to calling .mockReset() on every mocked function.

ãƒ¡ã‚½ãƒƒãƒ‰ãƒã‚§ãƒ¼ãƒ³ã®ãŸã‚ã«jestã‚ªãƒ–ã‚¸ã‚§ã‚¯ãƒˆã‚’è¿”ã—ã¾ã™ã€‚

jest.restoreAllMocks()â€‹

Restores all mocks and replaced properties back to their original value. Equivalent to calling .mockRestore() on every mocked function and .restore() on every replaced property. Beware that jest.restoreAllMocks() only works for mocks created with jest.spyOn() and properties replaced with jest.replaceProperty(); other mocks will require you to manually restore them.

Fake Timersâ€‹

jest.useFakeTimers(fakeTimersConfig?)â€‹

Instructs Jest to use fake versions of the global date, performance, time and timer APIs. Fake timers implementation is backed by @sinonjs/fake-timers.

Fake timers will swap out Date, performance.now(), queueMicrotask(), setImmediate(), clearImmediate(), setInterval(), clearInterval(), setTimeout(), clearTimeout() with an implementation that gets its time from the fake clock.

In Node environment process.hrtime, process.nextTick() and in JSDOM environment requestAnimationFrame(), cancelAnimationFrame(), requestIdleCallback(), cancelIdleCallback() will be replaced as well.

Configuration options:

type FakeableAPI =
  | 'Date'
  | 'hrtime'
  | 'nextTick'
  | 'performance'
  | 'queueMicrotask'
  | 'requestAnimationFrame'
  | 'cancelAnimationFrame'
  | 'requestIdleCallback'
  | 'cancelIdleCallback'
  | 'setImmediate'
  | 'clearImmediate'
  | 'setInterval'
  | 'clearInterval'
  | 'setTimeout'
  | 'clearTimeout';

type FakeTimersConfig = {
  /**
   * If set to `true` all timers will be advanced automatically by 20 milliseconds
   * every 20 milliseconds. A custom time delta may be provided by passing a number.
   * The default is `false`.
   */
  advanceTimers?: boolean | number;
  /**
   * List of names of APIs that should not be faked. The default is `[]`, meaning
   * all APIs are faked.
   */
  doNotFake?: Array<FakeableAPI>;
  /**
   * Use the old fake timers implementation instead of one backed by `@sinonjs/fake-timers`.
   * The default is `false`.
   */
  legacyFakeTimers?: boolean;
  /** Sets current system time to be used by fake timers. The default is `Date.now()`. */
  now?: number | Date;
  /**
   * The maximum number of recursive timers that will be run when calling `jest.runAllTimers()`.
   * The default is `100_000` timers.
   */
  timerLimit?: number;
};

Calling jest.useFakeTimers() will use fake timers for all tests within the file, until original timers are restored with jest.useRealTimers().

You can call jest.useFakeTimers() or jest.useRealTimers() from anywhere: top level, inside an test block, etc. Keep in mind that this is a global operation and will affect other tests within the same file. Calling jest.useFakeTimers() once again in the same test file would reset the internal state (e.g. timer count) and reinstall fake timers using the provided options:

test('advance the timers automatically', () => {
  jest.useFakeTimers({advanceTimers: true});
  // ...
});

test('do not advance the timers and do not fake `performance`', () => {
  jest.useFakeTimers({doNotFake: ['performance']});
  // ...
});

test('uninstall fake timers for the rest of tests in the file', () => {
  jest.useRealTimers();
  // ...
});
Legacy Fake Timers

For some reason you might have to use legacy implementation of fake timers. It can be enabled like this (additional options are not supported):

jest.useFakeTimers({
  legacyFakeTimers: true,
});

Legacy fake timers will swap out setImmediate(), clearImmediate(), setInterval(), clearInterval(), setTimeout(), clearTimeout() with Jest mock functions. In Node environment process.nextTick() and in JSDOM environment requestAnimationFrame(), cancelAnimationFrame() will be also replaced.

ãƒ¡ã‚½ãƒƒãƒ‰ãƒã‚§ãƒ¼ãƒ³ã®ãŸã‚ã«jestã‚ªãƒ–ã‚¸ã‚§ã‚¯ãƒˆã‚’è¿”ã—ã¾ã™ã€‚

jest.useRealTimers()â€‹

Instructs Jest to restore the original implementations of the global date, performance, time and timer APIs. For example, you may call jest.useRealTimers() inside afterEach hook to restore timers after each test:

afterEach(() => {
  jest.useRealTimers();
});

test('do something with fake timers', () => {
  jest.useFakeTimers();
  // ...
});

test('do something with real timers', () => {
  // ...
});

ãƒ¡ã‚½ãƒƒãƒ‰ãƒã‚§ãƒ¼ãƒ³ã®ãŸã‚ã«jestã‚ªãƒ–ã‚¸ã‚§ã‚¯ãƒˆã‚’è¿”ã—ã¾ã™ã€‚

jest.runAllTicks()â€‹

micro-task ã‚­ãƒ¥ãƒ¼ã‚’å‡¦ç†ã—ã¾ã™(é€šå¸¸ã¯nodeã§process.nextTickçµŒç”±ã§ã‚„ã‚Šå–ã‚Šã—ã¾ã™)ã€‚

ã“ã®APIãŒå‘¼ã°ã‚ŒãŸå ´åˆã€process.nextTickçµŒç”±ã§ã‚­ãƒ¥ãƒ¼ã‚¤ãƒ³ã‚°ã•ã‚ŒãŸå…¨ã¦ã®ä¿ç•™ä¸­ã®micro-taskãŒå®Ÿè¡Œã•ã‚Œã¾ã™ã€‚ ã•ã‚‰ã«ã€ãã‚Œã‚‰micro-taskè‡ªèº«ãŒæ–°ã—ã„micro-taskã‚’ã‚¹ã‚±ã‚¸ãƒ¥ãƒ¼ãƒ«ã—ã¦ã„ã‚‹å ´åˆã¯ã€ã‚­ãƒ¥ãƒ¼ã‹ã‚‰micro-taskãŒç„¡ããªã‚‹ã¾ã§ç¶™ç¶šçš„ã«å‡¦ç†ã•ã‚Œã¾ã™ã€‚

jest.runAllTimers()â€‹

Exhausts both the macro-task queue (i.e., all tasks queued by setTimeout(), setInterval(), and setImmediate()) and the micro-task queue (usually interfaced in node via process.nextTick).

When this API is called, all pending macro-tasks and micro-tasks will be executed. If those tasks themselves schedule new tasks, those will be continually exhausted until there are no more tasks remaining in the queue.

ã“ã®APIã¯ setTimeout() ã‚„ setInterval()ã‚³ãƒ¼ãƒ«ãƒãƒƒã‚¯ãŒå®Ÿè¡Œã•ã‚ŒãŸå¾Œã§ã®ã¿ç™ºç”Ÿã™ã‚‹ã‚ˆã†ãªå‹•ä½œã‚’åŒæœŸã—ã¦ç¢ºèªã™ã‚‹ãŸã‚ã«ã€ãƒ†ã‚¹ãƒˆä¸­ã«åŒæœŸçš„ã«setTimeoutsé–¢æ•°ã‚’å‹•ä½œã•ã›ã‚‹å ´åˆã«ä¾¿åˆ©ã§ã™ã€‚ è©³ç´°ã«ã¤ã„ã¦ã¯ Timer mocks ãƒ‰ã‚­ãƒ¥ãƒ¡ãƒ³ãƒˆã‚’å‚ç…§ã—ã¦ãã ã•ã„ã€‚

jest.runAllTimersAsync()â€‹

Asynchronous equivalent of jest.runAllTimers(). It allows any scheduled promise callbacks to execute before running the timers.

info

This function is not available when using legacy fake timers implementation.

jest.runAllImmediates()â€‹

setImmediate() ã«ã‚ˆã£ã¦ã‚­ãƒ¥ãƒ¼ã‚¤ãƒ³ã‚°ã•ã‚ŒãŸå…¨ã¦ã®ã‚¿ã‚¹ã‚¯ã‚’å‡¦ç†ã—ã¾ã™ã€‚

info

This function is only available when using legacy fake timers implementation.

jest.advanceTimersByTime(msToRun)â€‹

macro taskã‚­ãƒ¥ãƒ¼ã®ã¿ã‚’å®Ÿè¡Œã—ã¾ã™(ã¤ã¾ã‚Šã€ setTimeout() ã‹ setInterval() ã‚„ setImmediate()ã«ã‚ˆã£ã¦ã‚­ãƒ¥ãƒ¼ã‚¤ãƒ³ã‚°ã•ã‚ŒãŸå…¨ã¦ã®ã‚¿ã‚¹ã‚¯ã§ã™)ã€‚

ã“ã® API ãŒå‘¼ã³å‡ºã•ã‚Œã‚‹ã¨ã€ã™ã¹ã¦ã®ã‚¿ã‚¤ãƒãƒ¼ã¯ msToRun ãƒŸãƒªç§’ã§é€²ã¿ã¾ã™ã€‚ ã“ã®ã‚¿ã‚¤ãƒ ãƒ•ãƒ¬ãƒ¼ãƒ ã§å®Ÿè¡Œã•ã‚Œã‚‹ã§ã‚ã‚ã†ã€å…¨ã¦ã® setTimeout() ã¾ãŸã¯ setInterval() çµŒç”±ã§ã‚­ãƒ¥ãƒ¼ã‚¤ãƒ³ã‚°ã•ã‚ŒãŸä¿ç•™ä¸­ã® "macro-tasks" ãŒå®Ÿè¡Œã•ã‚Œã¾ã™ã€‚ Additionally, if those macro-tasks schedule new macro-tasks that would be executed within the same time frame, those will be executed until there are no more macro-tasks remaining in the queue, that should be run within msToRun milliseconds.

jest.advanceTimersByTimeAsync(msToRun)â€‹

Asynchronous equivalent of jest.advanceTimersByTime(msToRun). It allows any scheduled promise callbacks to execute before running the timers.

info

This function is not available when using legacy fake timers implementation.

jest.runOnlyPendingTimers()â€‹

ç¾æ™‚ç‚¹ã§ä¿ç•™ä¸­ã®macro-taskã®ã¿ã‚’å®Ÿè¡Œã—ã¾ã™(ã¤ã¾ã‚Šã“ã®æ™‚ç‚¹ã¾ã§ã«setTimeout() ã‹ setInterval()ã«ã‚ˆã£ã¦ã‚­ãƒ¥ãƒ¼ã‚¤ãƒ³ã‚°ã•ã‚ŒãŸã‚¿ã‚¹ã‚¯ã®ã¿ã§ã™)ã€‚ ãã®æ™‚ç‚¹ã§ä¿ç•™ä¸­ã® macro-tasksãŒæ–°ã—ã„ macro-taskã‚’ã‚¹ã‚±ã‚¸ãƒ¥ãƒ¼ãƒ«ã—ã¦ã„ã‚‹å ´åˆã€ãã‚Œã‚‰ã®æ–°ã—ã„ã‚¿ã‚¹ã‚¯ã¯ã“ã®APIã‹ã‚‰ã®å‘¼ã³å‡ºã—ã§ã¯å®Ÿè¡Œã•ã‚Œã¾ã›ã‚“ã€‚

ã“ã®APIã¯ãƒ†ã‚¹ãƒˆå¯¾è±¡ã®ãƒ¢ã‚¸ãƒ¥ãƒ¼ãƒ«ãŒsetTimeout()ãŒæ–°ãŸãªsetTimeout()ã‚’ã‚³ãƒ¼ãƒ«ãƒãƒƒã‚¯å†…ã§å†å¸°çš„ã«ã‚¹ã‚±ã‚¸ãƒ¥ãƒ¼ãƒ«ã—ã¦ã„ã‚‹ã‚ˆã†ãªã‚·ãƒŠãƒªã‚ªã«å½¹ç«‹ã¡ã¾ã™(ã‚³ãƒ¼ãƒ«ãƒãƒƒã‚¯å†…ã®ã‚¹ã‚±ã‚¸ãƒ¥ãƒ¼ãƒªãƒ³ã‚°ã¯åœæ­¢ã—ãªã„ã¨ã„ã†ã“ã¨ã§ã™) ã“ã‚Œã‚‰ã®ã‚·ãƒŠãƒªã‚ªã§ã¯ã€ä¸€åº¦ã«ï¼‘å›ãšã¤æ™‚é–“ã‚’é€²ã‚ã‚‹ã“ã¨ãŒã§ãã‚‹äº‹ãŒä¾¿åˆ©ãªã®ã§ã™ã€‚ ã“ã‚Œã‚‰ã®ã‚·ãƒŠãƒªã‚ªã§ã¯ã€ä¸€åº¦ã«ï¼‘å›ãšã¤æ™‚é–“ã‚’é€²ã‚ã‚‹ã“ã¨ãŒã§ãã‚‹äº‹ãŒä¾¿åˆ©ãªã®ã§ã™ã€‚

jest.runOnlyPendingTimersAsync()â€‹

Asynchronous equivalent of jest.runOnlyPendingTimers(). It allows any scheduled promise callbacks to execute before running the timers.

info

This function is not available when using legacy fake timers implementation.

jest.advanceTimersToNextTimer(steps)â€‹

Advances all timers by the needed milliseconds so that only the next timeouts/intervals will run.

Optionally, you can provide steps, so it will run steps amount of next timeouts/intervals.

jest.advanceTimersToNextTimerAsync(steps)â€‹

Asynchronous equivalent of jest.advanceTimersToNextTimer(steps). It allows any scheduled promise callbacks to execute before running the timers.

info

This function is not available when using legacy fake timers implementation.

jest.clearAllTimers()â€‹

ã‚¿ã‚¤ãƒãƒ¼ã‚·ã‚¹ãƒ†ãƒ ãŒä¿ç•™ã—ã¦ã„ã‚‹ã‚ã‚‰ã‚†ã‚‹ã‚¿ã‚¤ãƒãƒ¼ã‚’å‰Šé™¤ã—ã¾ã™ã€‚

ã¤ã¾ã‚Šã€(ã¾ã å®Ÿè¡Œã•ã‚Œã¦ã„ãªã„) ã‚¹ã‚±ã‚¸ãƒ¥ãƒ¼ãƒ«ã•ã‚ŒãŸå…¨ã¦ã®ã‚¿ã‚¤ãƒãƒ¼ã«ã¤ã„ã¦ã€å‰Šé™¤ã•ã‚Œã€å°†æ¥ã«ã‚ãŸã£ã¦å®Ÿè¡Œã•ã‚Œã‚‹ã“ã¨ã¯ãªã„ã¨ã„ã†äº‹ã§ã™ã€‚

jest.getTimerCount()â€‹

Returns the number of fake timers still left to run.

jest.now()â€‹

Returns the time in ms of the current clock. This is equivalent to Date.now() if real timers are in use, or if Date is mocked. In other cases (such as legacy timers) it may be useful for implementing custom mocks of Date.now(), performance.now(), etc.

jest.setSystemTime(now?: number | Date)â€‹

å½ã®ã‚¿ã‚¤ãƒãƒ¼ã§ä½¿ç”¨ã•ã‚Œã‚‹ç¾åœ¨ã‚·ã‚¹ãƒ†ãƒ æ™‚åˆ»ã‚’è¨­å®šã—ã¾ã™ã€‚ ãƒ—ãƒ­ã‚°ãƒ©ãƒ å®Ÿè¡Œä¸­ã®ãƒ¦ãƒ¼ã‚¶ãƒ¼ã«ã‚ˆã‚‹ã‚·ã‚¹ãƒ†ãƒ ã‚¯ãƒ­ãƒƒã‚¯ã®å¤‰æ›´ã™ã‚‹ã‚·ãƒŸãƒ¥ãƒ¬ãƒ¼ãƒˆã—ã¾ã™ã€‚ ç¾åœ¨ã®æ™‚åˆ»ã«å½±éŸ¿ã—ã¾ã™ãŒã€ä¾‹ãˆã°èµ·å‹•ã‚¿ã‚¤ãƒã®ã‚ˆã†ãªã€ãã‚Œè‡ªä½“ã®å†…éƒ¨ã§ç™ºç”Ÿã™ã‚‹ã‚‚ã®ã«ã¯å½±éŸ¿ã—ã¾ã›ã‚“ã€‚ jest.setSystemTime() ãŒå‘¼ã³å‡ºã•ã‚Œãªã‹ã£ãŸå ´åˆã¨åŒæ§˜ã«ã€æ­£ç¢ºã«èµ·å‹•ã—ã¾ã™ã€‚

info

This function is not available when using legacy fake timers implementation.

jest.getRealSystemTime()â€‹

æ™‚åˆ»ã‚’ãƒ¢ãƒƒã‚¯ã—ã¦ã„ã‚‹å ´åˆã€ Date.now() ã‚‚ãƒ¢ãƒƒã‚¯ã•ã‚Œã¾ã™ã€‚ ä½•ã‚‰ã‹ã®ç†ç”±ã§æœ¬å³¶ã®ç¾åœ¨æ™‚åˆ»ã«ã‚¢ã‚¯ã‚»ã‚¹ã™ã‚‹å¿…è¦ãŒã‚ã‚‹å ´åˆã¯ã€ã“ã®é–¢æ•°ã‚’å‘¼ã³å‡ºã™ã“ã¨ãŒã§ãã¾ã™ã€‚

info

This function is not available when using legacy fake timers implementation.

ãã®ä»–â€‹

jest.getSeed()â€‹

Every time Jest runs a seed value is randomly generated which you could use in a pseudorandom number generator or anywhere else.

tip

Use the --showSeed flag to print the seed in the test report summary. To manually set the value of the seed use --seed=<num> CLI argument.

jest.isEnvironmentTornDown()â€‹

Returns true if test environment has been torn down.

jest.retryTimes(numRetries, options?)â€‹

Runs failed tests n-times until they pass or until the max number of retries is exhausted.

jest.retryTimes(3);

test('will fail', () => {
  expect(true).toBe(false);
});

If logErrorsBeforeRetry option is enabled, error(s) that caused the test to fail will be logged to the console.

jest.retryTimes(3, {logErrorsBeforeRetry: true});

test('will fail', () => {
  expect(true).toBe(false);
});

ãƒ¡ã‚½ãƒƒãƒ‰ãƒã‚§ãƒ¼ãƒ³ã®ãŸã‚ã«jestã‚ªãƒ–ã‚¸ã‚§ã‚¯ãƒˆã‚’è¿”ã—ã¾ã™ã€‚

caution

jest.retryTimes() must be declared at the top level of a test file or in a describe block.

info

This function is only available with the default jest-circus runner.

jest.setTimeout(timeout)â€‹

Set the default timeout interval (in milliseconds) for all tests and before/after hooks in the test file. ã“ã‚Œã¯ã“ã®é–¢æ•°ãŒå‘¼ã³å‡ºã•ã‚ŒãŸãƒ†ã‚¹ãƒˆãƒ•ã‚¡ã‚¤ãƒ«ã«ã®ã¿å½±éŸ¿ã—ã¾ã™ã€‚ The default timeout interval is 5 seconds if this method is not called.

ä¾‹:

jest.setTimeout(1000); // 1 second
tip

To set timeout intervals on different tests in the same file, use the timeout option on each individual test.

If you want to set the timeout for all test files, use testTimeout configuration option.
